awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the prevalence of Silicon Valley-type clustering in industrial R&D activity in the U.S.  By assembling a comprehensive and detailed dataset on U.S. R&D-performing establishments whose activities aggregated to the regional level, it will generate the first systematic, geographical mapping of U.S. industrial R&D.  In addition to documenting the relative importance of Silicon Valley-style R&D agglomeration, the project will evaluate the determinants of the spatial distribution of R&D activity.  Specifically, the project will empirically estimate what factors raise or lower the likelihood that a firm locates its R&D facilities in a particular region.  The factors examined will include the presence of other establishments and firms performing R&D, the presence of the firm's manufacturing establishments, proximity to research universities, access to highly-educated and highly-specialized labor markets, and a region's intellectual property and tax policies.   A specific focus of the project will be the relationship between R&D and manufacturing. Some types of R&D are not easily disassociated from the manufacturing process and this has led in these instances to the co-location of R&D and manufacturing.  Because this project will document the evolution of the spatial distribution of R&D activities over the last three decades, it will shed light on how the off-shoring of the U.S. manufacturing industry has affected U.S. comparative advantage in R&D.  

Broader impacts:  This project will generate the first, systematic geographical mapping of U.S. industrial R&D using the Census-NSF Survey of Industrial R&D (SIRD) and in its successor survey the Business R&D and Innovation Survey (BRDIS).  This project will increase our understanding of how R&D in the U.S. is organized, and in particular the importance of agglomeration in R&D, of co-location of R&D and manufacturing, of geographically-mediated spillovers among R&D establishments and between research universities and industrial R&D, and of intellectual property considerations.   In addition, the results of this project will contribute to a wide range of policy discussions, including discussions of regional and national growth policy, industrial policy, intellectual property law, university research and its public funding, and the impact of higher education on the economy.

por.por_cntn:
We find that within the U.S. industrial R&D labs are highly concentrated in space. For example, if we rank the Census-defined Economic Areas (EA) by their numbers of R&D labs, the top ten EAs account for 53% of all the 1075 R&D labs in the U.S. in 1977. This share decreases to 48% in 2001. By comparison, manufacturing establishments are also geographically concentrated but less concentrated than R&D labs. If we rank the EAs by their numbers of manufacturing plants, the top ten EAs account for 45% of all manufacturing plants in 1977. This share decreases to 40% in 2001. To disentangle the combination of business, innovation and policy conditions that drives the concentration of industrial R&D labs, we study how individual firms decide where to open new R&D labs. We find that firms tend to open new R&D labs close to where they already have R&D, manufacturing, service or sales activities, possibly for convenience in control, communication and coordination within firm. We find that R&D labs are attracted to EAs with high industrial patents and high university patents that are relevant to the firms’ own business line, suggesting that firms take the knowledge spillovers from other innovating organizations into consideration when siting new R&D labs. Using firms’ patent citations as a measure for knowledge flow, we find that a firm absorbs more knowledge from an EA after the firm opens an R&D lab there than before. This effect is mediated by distance. A firm’s existing plants closer to the firm’s new R&D lab absorb more knowledge from the EA where the new R&D lab locates than the firm’s existing plants farther away do. A firm also absorbs more knowledge from an EA after the firm opens other types of establishments there than before, but to a much lesser extent. EAs with high basic research as measured by journal articles but not high patents do not attract new R&D labs. EAs with favorable R&D tax credit policies have independent attraction to new R&D labs even when local patents are controlled for. These findings suggest that, while industrial R&D clusters are self-strengthening, policy makers may make generous R&D tax policies or invest in applied research in local universities if they wish to make their locations more attractive to industrial R&D labs.
